docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Race Gap Seen in Health Care of Equally Insured Patients'' (front page, March 21):

headline.main: Now End the Racial Bias in Health Care

docs.abstract: Dr Alan R Fleischman letter on March 21 study says medical racism is unacceptable
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Race Gap Seen in Health Care of Equally Insured Patients'' (front page, March 21):

docs.lead_paragraph: Paul Hochenberg, the executive director of the Long Island Jewish Medical Center, was desperate to find more beds. So last year, as occupancy for his hospital climbed to more than 95 percent, he gave up his own office and his staff's so the hospital could convert the area to a 15-bed unit for patients who were being observed for a day or two. But the new unit did not solve the overcrowding, and Mr. Hochenberg now plans to seek state regulatory approval for as many as 100 new beds for the hospital, in New Hyde Park, N.Y.

headline.main: Patients Surge And Hospitals Hunt for Beds

docs.abstract: Many hospitals struggle to cope with surprising increases in number of patients, after years in which they closed beds and laid off workers; since 1985, number of hospitals has declined about 14 percent and number of beds declined 18 percent; at current levels, hospitals have almost no ability to handle unexpected increase in patients; some hospitals are being forced to turn away ambulances; at others, emergency room patients who are admitted wait hours or even days for rooms; reasons cited for increased demand for hospital rooms are: insurers have loosened their controls and now allow more patients to be treated in emergency rooms or overnight; many people have lost their jobs and their health insurance and now rely on emergency rooms as health care providers; aging baby boomers are more likely to experience serious illness or injury; experts are divided as to whether increase in patient visits is lasting change; photo; graphs (L)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Miami has allowed a group of managed care companies that have been accused of fraud to ask an appeals court for an immediate ruling on whether they are open to racketeering claims, a move that lawyers for both sides said could speed a final decision. The judge hearing the case, Federico A. Moreno of Federal District Court, ruled last month that the lawyers who represent health plan subscribers could proceed with claims of fraud under the Racketeering Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act against Aetna, Cigna and United Healthcare. Humana is also a RICO defendant under an earlier ruling.

headline.main: Judge Moves to Speed Along Lawsuit Over Managed Care

docs.abstract: Federal Judge Federico A Moreno allows group of managed care companies that have been accused of fraud to ask appeals court for immediate ruling on whether they are open to racketeering claims, move that lawyers for sides say could speed final decision; Moreno ruled last month that lawyers who represent health plan subscribers could proceed with claims of fraud under Racketeer Influenced and Corruption Organizations Act against Aetna, Cigna and United Healthcare; Humana is also RICO defendant under earlier ruling; plaintiffs contend health maintenance organizations violated racketeering law by conspiring to withhold medical care and by not telling HMO members that doctors were rewarded financially for doing so (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Before presenting his first budget proposal on Tuesday, Gov. James E. McGreevey promised to end the state's bad fiscal habits of excessive borrowing, profligate spending and reliance on one-time measures to increase state revenues. But state legislators and Wall Street analysts said today that the $23.66 billion spending plan proposed by Mr. McGreevey included some of the same flaws that have plagued New Jersey's budgets for years: understating the actual amount of state spending, using overly high predictions of state tax revenues and using one-time revenue sources for operating expenses.

headline.main: Budget Plan By McGreevey Raises Doubts

docs.abstract: New Jersey legislators and Wall Street analysts warn that $23.66-billion spending plan proposed by Gov James McGreevey contains some of same flaws that have plagued state's budgets for years, such as understating actual spending, using overly high revenue predictions and one-time revenue sources; McGreevey, who promised to end state's bad fiscal habits, did acccomplish difficult balancing act by closing projected $5.3-billion shortfall without resorting to unpopular tax increases, but he is relying heavily on borrowing and nonrecurring revenues; his photo (M)
docs.snippet: Before presenting his first budget proposal on Tuesday, Gov. James E. McGreevey promised to end the state's bad fiscal habits of excessive borrowing, profligate spending and reliance on one-time measures to increase state revenues.    But state...

docs.lead_paragraph: For all her skill in designing Web sites, Alicia Suarez made only $5,000 last year from 10 clients. So she did what many women here do to make ends meet -- she took a job in a call center, on the answering end of the ''800'' numbers that Americans dial so often to deal with the companies that sell to them. ''This may not be the best job, but in Albuquerque, it is better than the last job I had, waitressing tables,'' said Ms. Suarez, who is 21 and earns $9.50 an hour helping frustrated callers from around the country use Earthlink, an Internet service.

headline.main: Answering '800' Calls, Extra Income but No Security

docs.abstract: Call centers answering '800' number calls for companies are proliferating, adding jobs at faster pace than any other major occupation; some 3.5 million to 6 million people work in call centers, which are increasingly concentrated in lower-wage cities; centers draw mainly female employees, many of them second earners in their families; can be easily moved to lower-wage cities or even overseas, holding down wages and offering little job security; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A lawsuit accuses two of the state's largest insurers of withholding full reimbursement to health care providers. The suit, filed by about 80 doctors, therapists and nurses in the Franciscan Medical Group and Tacoma Orthopedic Surgeons Inc., says Premera Blue Cross and Regence Blue Shield systematically deny claims and delay payment of them. The plaintiffs are seek class-action status for the suit. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Suit Against Insurers

docs.abstract: Lawsuit in Washington accuses Premera Blue Cross and Regence Blue Shield, state's largest insurers, of withholding full reimbursement to health care providers (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The financial outlook for Social Security and Medicare improved in the last year, despite the recession, the Bush administration said today. The main reason for the improvement, it said, was an increase in the anticipated growth in the productivity of American workers in the coming decade and in the next 75 years.

headline.main: Report on Social Security Adds 3 Years to Fund's Life

docs.abstract: Trustees predict that Social Security trust fund will run out of money in 2041, three years later than estimated in 2001, assuming no change in current law, and that Medicare trust fund will run out of money in 2030, one year later than predicted in 2001; main reason for improvement is anticipated growth in productivity of American workers in coming decade and in next 75 years; White House says Congress should still shore up both programs before baby boomers reach retirement age (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Men's Reproductive Health Care Gets New Emphasis'' (March 19): To their credit, in recent years women's groups have kept women's health issues at the forefront of the media and the political process. The result -- on average, women in the United States live longer than men, 79.5 years versus 73.8 years. In New York, the Legislature has paid attention to women's issues, such as mandated insurance coverage for cervical cancer testing since 1992 and breast cancer testing since 1989.
docs.abstract: Lester Freundlich letter on March 19 article on men's reproductive health care holds gender gap between women's and men's health issues needs to be closed

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Bush Acts to Drop Core Privacy Rule on Medical Data'' (front page, March 22): The main problem with rules to protect medical privacy is that the horse has long since departed the barn. Medical confidentiality bolted the day doctors started working for insurance companies and the government rather than for their patients.
docs.abstract: Dr Richard Amerling letter on Mar 22 article holds medical confidentiality ended when doctors started working for insurance companies and government

docs.lead_paragraph: Imelda Rosario, a nanny on the Upper East Side, is so upset about being paid just $300 a week for 72 hours' work -- far less than the minimum wage -- that she has joined other domestic workers in an unusual fight. Those workers, who are largely invisible and wield little power, have banded together to press the City Council to enact what would be one of the nation's first laws to give stronger protections to nannies, baby sitters and housekeepers.

headline.main: Wage Bill Would Protect Housekeepers And Nannies

docs.abstract: Six New York City Council members plan to introduce legislation calling on families employing domestic workers to sign contracts to pay minimum wage, overtime and other benefits; photo (M)
